grid2bench package

Submodules

grid2bench.AgentsAnalytics module

This module allows to benchmark several agents in several scenarios through predefined KPIs (see KPI section).

The module uses the plotly package to visualize these KPIs in the form of graphs.

The modules load data in the forms EpisodesDataTransformer and EpisodesDataExtractor . You can access these objects like this:

from grid2bench.AgentsAnalytics import AgentsAnalytics

input_data_path = os.path.abspath('../data/input')
agents_names = ['Expert_Agent', 'IEE_PPO_Agent']
episodes_names = ['dec16_1', 'dec16_2']

# loading data
agents = AgentsAnalytics(
  data_path=input_data_path,
  agents_names=agents_names,
  episodes_names=episodes_names
)

# get indexes
expert_agent_idx = agents.agents_names.index('Expert_Agent')
dec16_2_idx = agents.episodes_names.index('dec16_2')

# access expert agent all episodes results --> EpisodesDataTransformer class
episodes = agents.agents_data[expert_agent_idx]
print('Loaded episodes for {} are : {}'.format(
  episodes.agent_name,
  episodes.episodes_names))

# access expert agent dec16_2 episode results --> EpisodeDataExtractor class
dec16_2 = agents.agents_data[expert_agent_idx].episodes_data[dec16_2_idx]
print('Episode name: {}'.format(dec16_2.episode_name))
class grid2bench.AgentsAnalytics.AgentsAnalytics(data_path: str, agents_names: Optional[List] = None, episodes_names: Optional[List] = None)[source]

Bases: object

This class is used to benchmark several agents in several scenarios.

It is also used to store agents’ episode results via the agents_data attribute

Attributes:

  • data_path: data folder path, parent directory path for agent log files

  • agents_names: list of agents names with the same name as the agent’s data folders

  • episodes_names: list of episode names with the same name as the episode data folders

  • agents_data: list of EpisodesDataTransformer

static cumulative_reward(agent_data: grid2bench.EpisodesDataTransformer.EpisodesDataTransformer, episodes_names: List)[source]

Helper function to transform cumulative rewards and accomplished time-steps into a data frame.

Extract cumulative rewards and completed time steps, then turn them into a time-series data frame.

Parameters

  • agent_data (EpisodeDataTransformer) – agent’s episodes log

  • episodes_names (list of str) – filter specific episodes. If none, returns results for all loaded episodes.

Returns

dataframe of cumulative reward and accomplished time-steps

Return type

pandas dataframe

Example of usage:

import os
from grid2bench.AgentsAnalytics import AgentsAnalytics

input_data_path = os.path.abspath('../data/input')
agents_names = ['Expert_Agent', 'IEE_PPO_Agent']
episodes_names = ['dec16_1', 'dec16_2']

# loading data
agents = AgentsAnalytics(
  data_path=input_data_path,
  agents_names=agents_names,
  episodes_names=episodes_names
)

agents_logs = agents.agents_data

# get expert agent index
expert_agent_idx = agents.agents_names.index('Expert_Agent')
expert_agent = agents_logs[expert_agent_idx]

df = AgentsAnalytics.cumulative_reward(
  expert_agent,
  episodes_names=episodes_names)
df
load_agents_results() → List[grid2bench.EpisodesDataTransformer.EpisodesDataTransformer][source]

Load agents’ episodes data from the episodes_names list.

Each element of the list contains agent’s episodes data as EpisodesDataTransformer

Returns

list of agents’ episodes

Return type

list of EpisodesDataTransformer

static plot_actions_freq_by_station(agents_results: List[grid2bench.EpisodesDataTransformer.EpisodesDataTransformer], episodes_names: Optional[List] = None, title: Optional[str] = 'Frequency of actions by station', **fig_kwargs)[source]

A bar chart representing the number of actions impacting each station and for each agent.

You can filter the agents to display by giving the list “agents_results” only to the desired agents.

Similarly, you can filter the episodes by giving the “episode_names” list only to the episodes you want to display. If episodes_names=None, then returns the results of all loaded episodes.

Parameters

  • agents_results (list of EpisodeDataTransformer) – list of agents episodes log, each item is a list of episode logs for an agent.

  • episodes_names (list of str) – filter specific episodes. If none, returns results for all loaded episodes.

  • title (str) – bar chart title, bar chart title, default value = ‘Frequency of actions by station’

  • fig_kwargs (**kwargs) – keyword arguments from the plotly library. Example: height= 700. For more arguments vist the plotly documentation https://plotly.com/python/

Returns

Barchart of frequency of impacted stations

Return type

Plotly figure

Example of usage:

import os
from grid2bench.AgentsAnalytics import AgentsAnalytics

input_data_path = os.path.abspath('../data/input')
agents_names = ['Expert_Agent', 'IEE_PPO_Agent']
episodes_names = ['dec16_1', 'dec16_2']

# loading data
agents = AgentsAnalytics(
  data_path=input_data_path,
  agents_names=agents_names,
  episodes_names=episodes_names
)

agents_logs = agents.agents_data
fig = AgentsAnalytics.plot_actions_freq_by_station(agents_logs)

fig.show()
static plot_actions_freq_by_station_pie_chart(agents_results: List[grid2bench.EpisodesDataTransformer.EpisodesDataTransformer], episodes_names: Optional[List] = None, title: str = 'Frequency of actions by station', row: int = 1, col: int = 2, **fig_kwargs)[source]

A Pie chart representing the number of actions impacting each station and for each agent. Similar to plot_actions_freq_by_station, but returns a pie chart instead

You can filter the agents to display by giving the list “agents_results” only to the desired agents.

Similarly, you can filter the episodes by giving the “episode_names” list only to the episodes you want to display. If episodes_names=None, then returns the results of all loaded episodes.

Parameters

  • agents_results (list of EpisodeDataTransformer) – list of agents episodes log, each item is a list of episode logs for an agent.

  • episodes_names (list of str) – filter specific episodes. If none, returns results for all loaded episodes.

  • title (str) – bar chart title, bar chart title, default value = ‘Frequency of actions by station’

  • row (int) – number of rows in plotly subplot

  • col (int) – number of columns in plotly subplot

  • fig_kwargs (**kwargs) – keyword arguments from the plotly library. Example: height= 700. For more arguments vist the plotly documentation https://plotly.com/python/

Returns

Barchart of frequency of impacted stations

Return type

Plotly figure

Example of usage:

import os
from grid2bench.AgentsAnalytics import AgentsAnalytics

input_data_path = os.path.abspath('../data/input')
agents_names = ['Expert_Agent', 'IEE_PPO_Agent']
episodes_names = ['dec16_1', 'dec16_2']

# loading data
agents = AgentsAnalytics(
  data_path=input_data_path,
  agents_names=agents_names,
  episodes_names=episodes_names
)

agents_logs = agents.agents_data
fig = AgentsAnalytics.plot_actions_freq_by_station_pie_chart(agents_logs)

fig.show()
static plot_actions_freq_by_type(agents_results: List[grid2bench.EpisodesDataTransformer.EpisodesDataTransformer], episodes_names: Optional[List] = None, title: Optional[str] = 'Frequency of actions by type', row: Optional[int] = 1, col: Optional[int] = 2, **fig_kwargs)[source]

A pie chart representing the frequency of unit actions by type.

Unit actions can be of type : switched lines, topological impacts, redispatching, storage and curtailment.

You can filter the agents to display by giving the list “agents_results” only to the desired agents.

Similarly, you can filter the episodes by giving the “episode_names” list only to the episodes you want to display. If episodes_names=None, then returns the results of all loaded episodes.

Parameters

  • agents_results (list of EpisodeDataTransformer) – list of agents episodes log, each item is a list of episode logs for an agent.

  • episodes_names (list of str) – filter specific episodes. If none, returns results for all loaded episodes.

  • title (str) – bar chart title, bar chart title, default value = ‘Frequency of actions by type’

  • row (int) – number of rows in plotly subplot

  • col (int) – number of columns in plotly subplot

  • fig_kwargs (**kwargs) – keyword arguments from the plotly library. Example: height= 700. For more arguments vist the plotly documentation https://plotly.com/python/

Returns

A pie chart of frequency of unit actions by type

Return type

plotly figure

Example of usage:

import os
from grid2bench.AgentsAnalytics import AgentsAnalytics

input_data_path = os.path.abspath('../data/input')
agents_names = ['Expert_Agent', 'IEE_PPO_Agent']
episodes_names = ['dec16_1', 'dec16_2']

# loading data
agents = AgentsAnalytics(
  data_path=input_data_path,
  agents_names=agents_names,
  episodes_names=episodes_names
)

agents_logs = agents.agents_data
fig = AgentsAnalytics.plot_actions_freq_by_type(agents_logs)

fig.show()
static plot_actions_sequence_length(agents_data: List[grid2bench.EpisodesDataTransformer.EpisodesDataTransformer], episodes_names: Optional[List] = None, title: str = 'Sequence length of actions', min_length: int = 0, max_length: int = 400, **fig_kwargs)[source]

Gantt diagram representing sequence actions for each agent.

A sequence of actions is defined by taking several actions in a non-disconnected sequence of time steps. A non-disconnected sequence means that there is no “do nothing” in the sequence.

Examples:

  • Sequence 1 : Switch bus action, Topological changes, Do nothing –> Sequence of length 2

  • Sequence 2 : Switch bus action, Do nothing, Topological changes –> not a sequence

  • Sequence 3 : Switch bus action, Topological changes, Do nothing, Switch bus action, Topological changes, Topological changes, Do nothing –> two sequences, the first of length 2 and the second of length 3

You can filter the agents to display by giving the list “agents_results” only to the desired agents.

Similarly, you can filter the episodes by giving the “episode_names” list only to the episodes you want to display. If episodes_names=None, then returns the results of all loaded episodes.

Parameters

  • agents_data (list of EpisodeDataTransformer) – list of agents episodes log, each item is a list of episode logs for an agent.

  • episodes_names (list of str) – filter specific episodes. If none, returns results for all loaded episodes.

  • title (str) – bar chart title, bar chart title, default value = ‘Distance from initial topology’

  • min_length (int) – filter only sequence actions greater than

  • max_length (int) – filter only asequence actions less than

  • fig_kwargs (**kwargs) – keyword arguments from the plotly library. Example: height= 700. For more arguments vist the plotly documentation https://plotly.com/python/

Returns

gantt chart of actions sequence

Return type

plotly figure

Example of usage:

import os
from grid2bench.AgentsAnalytics import AgentsAnalytics

input_data_path = os.path.abspath('../data/input')
agents_names = ['Expert_Agent', 'IEE_PPO_Agent']
episodes_names = ['dec16_1', 'dec16_2']

# loading data
agents = AgentsAnalytics(
  data_path=input_data_path,
  agents_names=agents_names,
  episodes_names=episodes_names
)

agents_logs = agents.agents_data

fig = AgentsAnalytics.plot_actions_sequence_length(
      agents_logs,
      episodes_names=['dec16_1'])
fig.show()
static plot_computation_times(agents_results: List[grid2bench.EpisodesDataTransformer.EpisodesDataTransformer], episodes_names: Optional[List] = None, title: str = 'Action Execution Time', **fig_kwargs)[source]

Time series line graph representing actions execution time at each timestamp and for each agent.

You can filter the agents to display by giving the list “agents_results” only to the desired agents.

Similarly, you can filter the episodes by giving the “episode_names” list only to the episodes you want to display. If episodes_names=None, then returns the results of all loaded episodes.

Parameters

  • agents_results (list of EpisodeDataTransformer) – list of agents episodes log, each item is a list of episode logs for an agent.

  • episodes_names (list of str) – filter specific episodes. If none, returns results for all loaded episodes.

  • title (str) – bar chart title, bar chart title, default value = ‘Action Execution Time’

  • fig_kwargs (**kwargs) – keyword arguments from the plotly library. Example: height= 700. For more arguments vist the plotly documentation https://plotly.com/python/

Returns

Time series line graph of actions execution times

Return type

plotly figure

Example of usage:

import os

input_data_path = os.path.abspath('../data/input')
agents_names = ['Expert_Agent', 'IEE_PPO_Agent']
episodes_names = ['dec16_1', 'dec16_2']

# loading data

  data_path=input_data_path,
  agents_names=agents_names,
  episodes_names=episodes_names
)

agents_logs = agents.agents_data

fig = AgentsAnalytics.plot_computation_times(
      agents_logs,
      episodes_names=['dec16_1'])
fig.show()
static plot_cumulative_reward(agents_data: List[grid2bench.EpisodesDataTransformer.EpisodesDataTransformer], episodes_names: Optional[List] = None, fig_type: Optional[str] = 'CumReward', title: Optional[str] = 'Cumulative reward per episode', **fig_kwargs)[source]

A bar graph representing the cumulative reward/accomplished time-steps per episodes for each agent.

If fig_type is default, plot cumulative rewards. If fig_type=’Acctimesteps’ then plot completed timesteps instead

You can filter the agents to display by giving the list “agents_results” only to the desired agents.

Similarly, you can filter the episodes by giving the “episode_names” list only to the episodes you want to display. If episodes_names=None, then returns the results of all loaded episodes.

Parameters

  • agents_data (list of EpisodeDataTransformer) – list of agents episodes log, each item is a list of episode logs for an agent.

  • episodes_names (list of str) – filter specific episodes. If none, returns results for all loaded episodes.

  • title (str) – bar chart title, bar chart title, default value = ‘Overloaded Lines by station’

  • fig_type (str) – diagram type: cumulative reward per episode or accomplished time-steps per episode. Default = cumulative reward, else accomplished time-steps

  • fig_kwargs (**kwargs) – keyword arguments from the plotly library. Example: height= 700. For more arguments vist the plotly documentation https://plotly.com/python/

Returns

Barchart of cumulative rewards/accomplished time-steps

Return type

plotly figure

static plot_distance_from_initial_topology(agents_results: List[grid2bench.EpisodesDataTransformer.EpisodesDataTransformer], episodes_names: Optional[List] = None, title: str = 'Distance from initial topology', **fig_kwargs)[source]

line chart representing the number of changes compared to the initial topology at each timestamp and for each agent.

You can filter the agents to display by giving the list “agents_results” only to the desired agents.

Similarly, you can filter the episodes by giving the “episode_names” list only to the episodes you want to display. If episodes_names=None, then returns the results of all loaded episodes.

Parameters

  • agents_results (list of EpisodeDataTransformer) – list of agents episodes log, each item is a list of episode logs for an agent.

  • episodes_names (list of str) – filter specific episodes. If none, returns results for all loaded episodes.

  • title (str) – bar chart title, bar chart title, default value = ‘Distance from initial topology’

  • fig_kwargs (**kwargs) – keyword arguments from the plotly library. Example: height= 700. For more arguments vist the plotly documentation https://plotly.com/python/

Returns

Time series line graph of actions execution times

Return type

plotly figure

Example of usage:

import os
from grid2bench.AgentsAnalytics import AgentsAnalytics

input_data_path = os.path.abspath('../data/input')
agents_names = ['Expert_Agent', 'IEE_PPO_Agent']
episodes_names = ['dec16_1', 'dec16_2']

# loading data
agents = AgentsAnalytics(
  data_path=input_data_path,
  agents_names=agents_names,
  episodes_names=episodes_names
)

agents_logs = agents.agents_data

fig = AgentsAnalytics.plot_distance_from_initial_topology(
      agents_logs,
      episodes_names=['dec16_1'])
fig.show()
static plot_lines_impact(agents_results: List[grid2bench.EpisodesDataTransformer.EpisodesDataTransformer], episodes_names: Optional[List] = None, title: str = 'Overloaded Lines by station', fig_type: str = 'overloaded', **fig_kwargs)[source]

A bar chart representing the frequency of actions impacts on each power lines and for each agent.

Two possible type of impacts : Line overflow impact, default value or fig_type =’disconnected’. And line overflow impact, can be obtained by giving fig_type =’disconnected’.

You can filter the agents to display by giving the list “agents_results” only to the desired agents.

Similarly, you can filter the episodes by giving the “episode_names” list only to the episodes you want to display. If episodes_names=None, then returns the results of all loaded episodes.

Parameters

  • agents_results (list of EpisodeDataTransformer) – list of agents episodes log, each item is a list of episode logs for an agent.

  • episodes_names (list of str) – filter specific episodes. If none, returns results for all loaded episodes.

  • title (str) – bar chart title, bar chart title, default value = ‘Overloaded Lines by station’

  • fig_type (str) – diagram type: frequency of overloaded lines or frequency of disconnected lines. Default = overloaded, else disconnected

  • fig_kwargs (**kwargs) – keyword arguments from the plotly library. Example: height= 700. For more arguments vist the plotly documentation https://plotly.com/python/

Returns

Barchart of frequency of impacted lines

Return type

plotly figure

Example of usage:

import os
from grid2bench.AgentsAnalytics import AgentsAnalytics

input_data_path = os.path.abspath('../data/input')
agents_names = ['Expert_Agent', 'IEE_PPO_Agent']
episodes_names = ['dec16_1', 'dec16_2']

# loading data
agents = AgentsAnalytics(
  data_path=input_data_path,
  agents_names=agents_names,
  episodes_names=episodes_names
)

agents_logs = agents.agents_data

# overflowed lines
fig_overflowed_lines = AgentsAnalytics.plot_lines_impact(agents_logs)
fig_overflowed_lines.show()

# disconnected lines
fig_disconnected_lines = AgentsAnalytics.plot_lines_impact(
agents_logs,
fig_type='disconnected')
fig_disconnected_lines.show()

grid2bench.EpisodeDataExtractor module

This module is used to extract only the information we need from the agent log files generated by the grid2op package

Log files are obtained either by evaluating agent performance using the L2RPN score or by running the agent using the Runner class in grid2op.

Typical usage example of the module:

from grid2bench.EpisodeDataExtractor import EpisodeDataExtractor
from datetime import datetime
import numpy as np

# import episode data
agent_log_path = '../data/input/Expert_Agent'
episode_name = 'dec16_1'
episode_data = EpisodeDataExtractor(agent_log_path, episode_name)

date_time = datetime(year=2012, month=12, day=4, hour=7, minute=5)

act = episode_data.get_action_by_timestamp(date_time)
obs = episode_data.get_observation_by_timestamp(date_time)

line_statuses = obs.line_status
subs_on_bus_2 = np.repeat(False, obs.n_sub)
objs_on_bus_2 = {id: [] for id in range(obs.n_sub)}

distance, _, _, _ = episode_data.get_distance_from_obs(
act,
line_statuses,
subs_on_bus_2,
objs_on_bus_2,
obs)

print('Distance from initial topology of the second action is :', distance)
class grid2bench.EpisodeDataExtractor.EpisodeDataExtractor(agent_log_path: str, episode_name: str)[source]

Bases: object

This class is used to extract and transform data from agent evaluation results log files.

Extract only the useful information for us from grid2op’s EpisodeData class to reduce memory size, then prepare this data to calculate evaluation metrics.

Attributes:

  • agent_log_path: agent’s log file path

  • agent_name: agent’s name, as the same name as the agent folder

  • episode_name: episode name as the same name as the episode folder

  • observations: list of observations in the episode

  • actions: list of actions in the episode

  • n_observation: number of observations in the episode

  • n_action: number of actions in the episode, usually n_observation -1

  • timestamps: list of episode timestamps

  • computation_times: list of agent’s action execution times

  • cum_reward: cumulative reward of the episode

  • max_timestep: maximum time steps in the episode

  • nb_timestep_played: number of played time steps completed in the episode before a game over.

actions_freq_by_timestamp() → pandas.core.frame.DataFrame[source]

Calculate the number of unit actions in the episode.

Unit actions including switched lines, topological impacts, redispatching, storage and curtailment.

Returns

a DataFrame time series with columns: Timestamp, nb of unit actions, impacted substations and impacted lines.

Return type

DataFrame

Example of usage:

from grid2bench.EpisodeDataExtractor import EpisodeDataExtractor

# import episode data
agent_log_path = '../data/input/Expert_Agent'
episode_name = 'dec16_1'
episode_data = EpisodeDataExtractor(agent_log_path, episode_name)

df = episode_data.actions_freq_by_timestamp()
print(df)
actions_freq_by_type() → pandas.core.frame.DataFrame[source]

Returns the number of unit actions by type whitin the episode

Unit actions including switched lines, topological impacts, redispatching, storage and curtailment.

Returns

Actions frequency of : NB line switched, NB topological change, NB redispatching, NB storage changes, NB curtailment

Return type

DataFrame

Example of usage :

from grid2bench.EpisodeDataExtractor import EpisodeDataExtractor

# import episode data
agent_log_path = '../data/input/Expert_Agent'
episode_name = 'dec16_1'
episode_data = EpisodeDataExtractor(agent_log_path, episode_name)

df = episode_data.actions_freq_by_type()
print(df)
compute_action_sequences_length() → pandas.core.frame.DataFrame[source]

Calculate the length of action sequence in an episode.

A sequence of actions is defined by taking several actions in a non-disconnected sequence of time steps. A non-disconnected sequence means that there is no “do nothing” in the sequence.

Examples:

  • Sequence 1 : Switch bus action, Topological changes, Do nothing –> Sequence of length 2

  • Sequence 2 : Switch bus action, Do nothing, Topological changes –> not a sequence

  • Sequence 3 : Switch bus action, Topological changes, Do nothing, Switch bus action, Topological changes, Topological changes, Do nothing –> two sequences, the first of length 2 and the second of length 3

Returns

a DataFrame time series with columns: Timestamp, Sequence length, NB action, Impacted subs, Impacted lines

Return type

DataFrame

Example of usage :

from grid2bench.EpisodeDataExtractor import EpisodeDataExtractor

# import episode data
agent_log_path = '../data/input/Expert_Agent'
episode_name = 'dec16_1'
episode_data = EpisodeDataExtractor(agent_log_path, episode_name)

df_actions_sequence = episode_data.compute_action_sequences_length()
print(df_actions_sequence)

disconnected_lines_by_timestamp() → List[Dict[datetime.datetime, Set]][source]

Returns disconnected lines at each episode timestamp

Returns

disconnected lines impacted by agent actions

Return type

a list of dictionaries {Timestamp, Disconnected lines}

from grid2bench.EpisodeDataExtractor import EpisodeDataExtractor

# import episode data

episode_name = 'dec16_1'
episode_data = EpisodeDataExtractor(agent_log_path, episode_name)

get_action_by_timestamp(date_time: datetime.datetime) → grid2op.Action.BaseAction.BaseAction[source]

Get the grid2op action object whose timestamp is date_time.

Parameters

date_time (datetime) – the datetime sought

Returns

Action if exists otherwise raise Error

Return type

grid2op.BaseAction object

Example of usage:

from grid2bench.EpisodeDataExtractor import EpisodeDataExtractor
from datetime import datetime

# import episode data
agent_log_path = '../data/input/Expert_Agent'
episode_name = 'dec16_1'
episode_data = EpisodeDataExtractor(agent_log_path, episode_name)

date_time = datetime(year=2012, month=12, day=4, hour=7, minute=0)
act = episode_data.get_observation_by_timestamp(date_time)
print(act)
get_action_id(action)[source]
get_computation_time_by_timestamp(date_time: datetime.datetime) → float[source]

Get agent action execution time at timestamp date_time.

Parameters

date_time (datetime) – the datetime sought

Returns

action execution time in seconds if found, raise an error otherwise

Return type

float

Example of usage:

from grid2bench.EpisodeDataExtractor import EpisodeDataExtractor
from datetime import datetime

# import episode data
agent_log_path = '../data/input/Expert_Agent'
episode_name = 'dec16_1'
episode_data = EpisodeDataExtractor(agent_log_path, episode_name)

date_time = datetime(year=2012, month=12, day=4, hour=7, minute=0)
execution_time = episode_data.get_computation_time_by_timestamp(
date_time)
print(execution_time, 's')
get_distance_from_obs(act, line_statuses, subs_on_bus_2, objs_on_bus_2, obs)[source]

Calculate the number of changes compared to the initial topology

A function reused from grid2vis package ( https://github.com/rte-france/grid2viz)

Parameters

  • act (grid2op.BaseAction object) – the agent’s action

  • line_statuses (list) – line status (connected/disconnected)

  • subs_on_bus_2 (list) – substation connected on buses 2

  • objs_on_bus_2 (list) – objects connected on buses 2

  • obs (grid2op.BaseObservation) – observation

Returns

distance, line_statuses, subs_on_bus_2, objs_on_bus_2

Return type

tuple

get_observation_by_timestamp(date_time: datetime.datetime) → grid2op.Observation.baseObservation.BaseObservation[source]

Get the grid2op observation object whose timestamp is date_time.

Parameters

date_time (datetime) – the datetime sought

Returns

Observation if exists otherwise raise Error

Return type

grid2op.BaseObservation object

Example of usage:

from grid2bench.EpisodeDataExtractor import EpisodeDataExtractor
from datetime import datetime

# import episode data
agent_log_path = '../data/input/Expert_Agent'
episode_name = 'dec16_1'
episode_data = EpisodeDataExtractor(agent_log_path, episode_name)

date_time = datetime(year=2012, month=12, day=4, hour=7, minute=0)
obs = episode_data.get_observation_by_timestamp(date_time)
print(obs.to_vect())
get_timestep_by_datetime(date_time: datetime.datetime) → int[source]

Get the order of a given timestamp in the episode.

Parameters

date_time (datetime) – datetime sought

Returns

order of the date_time, raise an error otherwise

Return type

int

Example of usage:

from grid2bench.EpisodeDataExtractor import EpisodeDataExtractor
from datetime import datetime

# import episode data
agent_log_path = '../data/input/Expert_Agent'
episode_name = 'dec16_1'
episode_data = EpisodeDataExtractor(agent_log_path, episode_name)

date_time = datetime(year=2012, month=12, day=4, hour=7, minute=10)
timestep = episode_data.get_timestep_by_datetime(date_time)
print('The timestep of {} is {}'.format(date_time, timestep))

update_objs_on_bus(objs_on_bus_2, elem, topo_vect_dict, kind)[source]
static update_objs_on_bus_assign(objs_on_bus_2, elem, pos_topo_vect)[source]
static update_objs_on_bus_switch(objs_on_bus_2, elem, pos_topo_vect)[source]

grid2bench.EpisodesDataTransformer module

This module is used to transform data already extracted using the EpisodeDataExtractor class, and to prepare it for visualization.

The module is also used to store several episode information for later use, such as metrics evaluation

Typical usage example of the module:

from grid2bench.EpisodesDataTransformer import EpisodesDataTransformer

agent_log_path = '../data/input/Expert_Agent'
episode_names = ['dec16_1', 'dec16_2']

# loading episodes data
expert_agent = EpisodesDataTransformer(agent_log_path, episode_names)

# sequence actions for all loaded episodes
df1 = expert_agent.actions_freq_by_type_several_episodes()
print('Frequency of actions by type for all episodes \n',df1)

# sequence actions for only selected episodes
episodes_names = ['dec16_1']
df2 = expert_agent.actions_freq_by_type_several_episodes(
      episodes_names=['dec16_1'])
print('Frequency of actions by type for dec16_1 episode \n', df2)
class grid2bench.EpisodesDataTransformer.EpisodesDataTransformer(agent_path: str, episodes_names: list)[source]

Bases: object

This class is used to load multiple episode data at once and then prepare it for analysis based to specific metrics.

Attributes:

  • agent_path: agent’s log file path

  • agent_name: agent’s name, as the same name as the agent folder

  • episodes_names: list of episode names with the same name as the episode data folder

  • episodes_data: list of EpisodeDataExtractor

  • n_lines: number lines in the power grid

  • n_episode: number of episodes loaded in episodes_data

action_sequences_to_dict(episodes_names: Optional[List] = None, min_length: int = 0, max_length: int = 400) → List[Dict][source]

Helper function to transform sequence of actions df to dict.

Transform the data structure and prepare it for plotting with plotly’s gantt chart

Parameters

  • episodes_names (list of str) – filter specific episodes. If none, returns results for all loaded episodes.

  • min_length (int) – minimum length of sequence

  • max_length (int) – maximum length of sequence

Returns

a dictionary list of : Type, Start, Finish, Actions,

Actions_percent. :rtype: dictionary list

actions_freq_by_station_several_episodes(episodes_names: Optional[List] = None) → pandas.core.frame.DataFrame[source]

Returns the impacted substations at each timestamp for all episodes in episodes_names.

If episodes_names=None, then returns the results of all loaded episodes.

Returns

impacted substations by agent actions

Return type

a list of dictionaries {Timestamp, Sub impacted}

Example of usage:

from grid2bench.EpisodesDataTransformer import EpisodesDataTransformer

agent_log_path = '../data/input/Expert_Agent'

# all loaded episodes

print('Frequency of actions by station for all episodes \n',df1)

# selected episodes

          episodes_names=['dec16_1'])
print('Frequency of actions by station for dec16_1 episode \n', df2)
actions_freq_by_type_several_episodes(episodes_names: Optional[List] = None) → pandas.core.frame.DataFrame[source]

Returns the number of unit actions by type for all episodes in episodes_names

If episodes_names=None, then returns the results of all loaded episodes.

Unit actions including switched lines, topological impacts, redispatching, storage and curtailment.

Parameters

episodes_names (list of str) – filter specific episodes. If none, returns results for all loaded episodes.

Returns

Actions frequency of : NB line switched, NB topological change, NB redispatching, NB storage changes, NB curtailment

DataFrame

Example of usage:

from grid2bench.EpisodesDataTransformer import EpisodesDataTransformer

agent_log_path = '../data/input/Expert_Agent'
episode_names = ['dec16_1', 'dec16_2']

# loading episodes data
expert_agent = EpisodesDataTransformer(agent_log_path, episode_names)

# actions frequency by type for all loaded episodes
df1 = expert_agent.actions_freq_by_type_several_episodes()
print('Frequency of actions by type for all episodes \n',df1)

# actions frequency for only selected episodes

df2 = expert_agent.actions_freq_by_type_several_episodes(
          episodes_names=['dec16_1'])
print('Frequency of actions by type for dec16_1 episode \n', df2)

Action execution times at each timestamp for all episodes in episodes_names.

If episodes_names=None, then returns the results of all loaded episodes.

Parameters

Returns

a dataframe of execution times (s) at each timestamp

DataFrame

# all loaded episodes

          episodes_names=['dec16_1'])

display_detailed_action_type(episodes_names: Optional[List] = None)[source]
display_sequence_actions(episodes_names: Optional[List] = None, min_length: int = 0, max_length: int = 400) → pandas.core.frame.DataFrame[source]

Return sequence of actions as a flattened list for all episodes in episodes_names.

If episodes_names=None, then returns the results of all loaded episodes.

A sequence of actions is defined by taking several actions in a non-disconnected sequence of time steps. A non-disconnected sequence means that there is no “do nothing” in the sequence.

Examples:

  • Sequence 1 : Switch bus action, Topological changes, Do nothing –> Sequence of length 2

  • Sequence 2 : Switch bus action, Do nothing, Topological changes –> not a sequence

  • Sequence 3 : Switch bus action, Topological changes, Do nothing, Switch bus action, Topological changes, Topological changes, Do nothing –> two sequences, the first of length 2 and the second of length 3

Parameters

  • episodes_names (list of str) – filter specific episodes. If none, returns results for all loaded episodes.

  • min_length (int) – minimum length of sequence

  • max_length (int) – maximum length of sequence

Returns

a DataFrame with columns: Timestamp, Sequence start, Sequence end, Sequence length, NB actions, NB unitary actions, Impacted Subs, Impacted lines

Return type

DataFrame

Example of usage:

from grid2bench.EpisodesDataTransformer import EpisodesDataTransformer

agent_log_path = '../data/input/Expert_Agent'
episode_names = ['dec16_1', 'dec16_2']

# loading episodes data
expert_agent = EpisodesDataTransformer(agent_log_path, episode_names)

# filter selected episodes
episodes_names = ['dec16_1']
df = expert_agent.display_sequence_actions(
  episodes_names=['dec16_1'],
  min_length= 0,
  max_length=15)
print('Sequence actions in dec16_1 episode \n', df)
display_sequence_actions_filter(episodes_names: Optional[List] = None, min_length: int = 0, max_length: int = 400)[source]

Display sequence actions as separate dataframes for all episodes in episodes_names.

If episodes_names=None, then returns the results of all loaded episodes.

A sequence of actions is defined by taking several actions in a non-disconnected sequence of time steps. A non-disconnected sequence means that there is no “do nothing” in the sequence.

Parameters

  • episodes_names (list of str) – filter specific episodes. If none, returns results for all loaded episodes.

  • min_length (int) – minimum length of sequence

  • max_length (int) – maximum length of sequence

Returns

a DataFrame time series with columns: Timestamp, Sequence length, NB unitary actions, Impacted subs, Impacted lines

Return type

DataFrame

Example of usage:

from grid2bench.EpisodesDataTransformer import EpisodesDataTransformer

episode_names = ['dec16_1', 'dec16_2']

# loading episodes data

# filter selected episodes
episodes_names = ['dec16_1']
expert_agent.display_sequence_actions_filter(
  episodes_names=['dec16_1'],
  min_length=1,
  max_length=15)

get_sequence_actions(episodes_names: Optional[List] = None) → pandas.core.frame.DataFrame.groupby[source]

Return sequence actions as grouped dataframe for all episodes in episodes_names.

If episodes_names=None, then returns the results of all loaded episodes.

A sequence of actions is defined by taking several actions in a non-disconnected sequence of time steps. A non-disconnected sequence means that there is no “do nothing” in the sequence.

Examples:

  • Sequence 1 : Switch bus action, Topological changes, Do nothing –> Sequence of length 2

  • Sequence 2 : Switch bus action, Do nothing, Topological changes –> not a sequence

  • Sequence 3 : Switch bus action, Topological changes, Do nothing, Switch bus action, Topological changes, Topological changes, Do nothing –> two sequences, the first of length 2 and the second of length 3

Parameters

episodes_names (list of str) – filter specific episodes. If none, returns results for all loaded episodes.

Returns

a DataFrame time series with columns: Timestamp, Sequence length, NB action, Impacted subs, Impacted lines

Return type

DataFrame

Example of usage :

from grid2bench.EpisodesDataTransformer import EpisodesDataTransformer

agent_log_path = '../data/input/Expert_Agent'
episode_names = ['dec16_1', 'dec16_2']

# loading episodes data
expert_agent = EpisodesDataTransformer(agent_log_path, episode_names)

# filter selected episodes
episodes_names = ['dec16_1']
df = expert_agent.get_sequence_actions(
          episodes_names=['dec16_1'])
print('First sequence of actions in dec16_1 episode \n', df.first())
